summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) policy manual (P6360.01) establishing comprehensive guidelines for pharmacy services within federal correctional institutions. It details procedures for staffing, drug formulary management, controlled substance security, dispensing, and patient safety. The document is a standard operating procedure and contains no direct references to the Epstein case, individuals, or specific events. This document is a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) Program Statement (P6360.01) detailing comprehensive policies and procedures for pharmacy services, with a heavy focus on the secure handling, inventory, dispensing, and administration of controlled substances within federal correctional institutions. It outlines roles, responsibilities, and strict protocols to prevent diversion and ensure accountability. This is a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) policy document (P6360.01) detailing comprehensive procedures for medication management, error reporting, adverse drug reactions, and specific protocols for controlled substances like methadone within federal correctional institutions. It outlines responsibilities for prescribers, pharmacists, and other staff, and includes detailed guidelines for inmate medication upon release or transfer.

persons.name: Chief Pharmacist

persons.name: Warden
persons.context: The institutional head who must be notified of any theft or loss of controlled substances and who is responsible for reporting such incidents to the DEA.

persons.name: HSA
persons.context: The health services supervisor who designates the chair of the Controlled Substances Inventory Team and receives memos regarding theft or loss of drugs.

persons.name: BOP Chief Pharmacist

persons.name: Medical Director
persons.context: The official who must be contacted for guidance if an institution is without pharmacist services for more than three days.

persons.name: Chief Psychiatrist

persons.name: Chief of Psychology

keyFacts: This is a standard BOP policy document (P6360.01) on Pharmacy Services, dated January 15, 2005.
The document outlines strict protocols for the management, dispensing, and security of medications, particularly DEA-controlled substances, within federal prisons.
It establishes the Chief Pharmacist as the responsible authority for all controlled substances and details requirements for inventory, record-keeping, and key control.
The policy references the use of automated medication administration cabinets (e.g., Pyxis) and the Bureau Correctional Institution Pharmacy System (CIPS) software.
The document is purely procedural and contains no case-specific information, names, or events related to Jeffrey Epstein or his associates.
This is a standard BOP policy document (P6360.01) on pharmacy services, not a case-specific investigative file or record related to Jeffrey Epstein.

The document focuses entirely on institutional procedures for drug security, inventory, and administration within the federal prison system, with no mention of Epstein, his associates, victims, or properties.
It mandates strict protocols for controlled substances, including biennial inventories, quarterly audit teams, and detailed reporting of thefts to the DEA via Form 106.
The policy emphasizes direct observation of medication ingestion by inmates ('pill line') to prevent diversion and 'cheeking'.
It outlines contingency plans for pharmacist coverage, including contracts, interagency agreements, and temporary duty assignments from other institutions.
This is a standard Bureau of Prisons (BOP) policy document (P6360.01) dated January 15, 2005, governing pharmacy services and medication management within federal correctional institutions.

The document establishes detailed protocols for medication error reporting, classification (Levels 0-6, with Level 6 being patient death), and review by a Quality Improvement Program (QIP) coordinator and Chief Pharmacist.
It specifies strict procedures for the control, inventory, and storage of needles and syringes to prevent misuse, requiring shift inventories and secure, locked storage.

The policy outlines the approved uses of methadone within BOP facilities: treatment of opiate-addicted pregnant inmates, detoxification of opiate-addicted inmates, and treatment of severe pain, with varying regulatory requirements for each use.

Procedures for providing inmates with medication upon release (30-day supply) or transfer to a Community Corrections Center (CCC) are detailed, including special considerations for controlled substances and HIV/AIDS medications.
